title: tyler the creator igor stream tracklist features credits kanye playboi carti
story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsAlbum includes a track that nods to Call Me By Your NameClick to followThe Independent CultureTyler, the Creator attends the 60th Annual Grammy AwardsTyler, the Creator has released his anticipated new album IGOR.The record serves as the follow-up to his acclaimed 2017 LP Flower Boy, and includes credits for Kanye West, Lil Uzi Vert, Al Green, Playboi Carti and Cullen Omori (formerly of Smith Westerns) as co-writers.&nbspWest is not credited as a featured artist but can be heard on the track “Puppet”.&nbspCreated with Sketch.The best albums of 2019 (so far) Show all 32Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.It’s not uncommon for an artist to be influenced by the place they grew up in. Yet few are likely to have as much inspiration to draw on as India-born, Zimbabwe-raised and now Peckham-based artist Rina Mushonga.On Deerhunter’s eighth album, frontman Bradford Cox takes on the role of war poet, documenting the things he observes with a cool matter-of-factness, and heart-wrenching detail. Death is everywhere on Why Hasn’t Everything Already Disappeared?, as much as others may refuse to see it.After a period of tumult, Sharon Van Etten’s fifth album is a reinvention. But beneath its hazy synths and electronics are songs of endurance and inner peace, of settling after a flurry of activity. 432 Bring Me the Horizon  – AmoBMTH frontman Oli Sykes wants to assert the fragility of the boundary between love and hate. Amo is a way of exploring that, even down to the title itself.532 Nina Nesbitt – The Sun Will Come Up, the Seasons Will ChangeNesbitt is back with her second LP, switching to a brand of soul and R&ampB-fused pop that feels bang on time, and suits her far better. The Sun Will Come Up, the Seasons Will Change has slick, polished production from Fraser T Smith (Adele), Lostboy (Anne-Marie), Jordan Riley (Zara Larsson), and Nesbitt herself.This self-titled record, a loose but beautifully crafted collection of folk-rock songs, explores the kinds of anxieties intrinsic to the modern age – the longing to be at once noticed and invisible the paralysing effects of limitless information, and the desire to do good versus the desire to be seen doing good.The album is packed with personal confessions for the fans – “Arianators” – to pick over. It lacks a centrepiece to match the arresting depth and space of Sweetener’s “God Is A Woman”, but Grande handles its shifting moods and cast of producers (including pop machines Max Martin and Tommy Brown) with engaging class and momentum. One minute you’re skanking along to the party brass of “Bloodline” the next floating into the semi-detached, heartbreak of “Ghostin’”, which appears to address Grande’s guilt at being with Davidson while pining for Miller. She sings of the late rapper as a “wingless angel” with featherlight high notes that will drop the sternest jaw. (Helen Brown)The perma-brilliant James Blake has flooded his fourth album – Assume Form – with euphoric sepia soul and loved-up doo-wop. His trademark intelligence, honesty and pin-drop production remain intact. But the detached chorister vocals of a decade in which he battled depression have thawed to reveal a millennial Sam Cooke crooning: “Can’t believe the way we flow, way we flow, way we flow...”While he recognises his roots and includes plenty of nods to grime, AJ Tracey's magpie’s eye for a good melody or hook extends far beyond that. With the help of stellar producers like Cadenza (Kiko Bun), Swifta Beater (Kano, Giggs), and Nyge (Section Boyz, Yxng Bane), Tracey incorporates electronic music, rock, garage and even country on his most cohesive work to date.The album title of the year gives us an image of Brexit Britain trashed by Old Etonians David Cameron, Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg, but the fifth studio work from the punk duo has more than social commentary to offer. There’s some of that, as vocalist Jason Williamson skewers documentary-makers who take advantage of the poor in “Kebab Spider” – “the skint get used in loo roll shoes” – but elsewhere this is a record that expands the idea of what Sleaford Mods could be.“Do you still have that photograph? Would you use it to hurt me?” asks Australian indie rocker Julia Jacklin, against the menacing throb of “Body”. The tension is stormy: imagine a mid-period Fleetwood Mac song, covered by Cat Power. It’s a masterclass in narrative songwriting.With praise from Kendrick Lamar, five EPs released by the time she was 21, tours with Lauryn Hill, collaborations with Gorillaz and two critically praised albums – including 2017’s excellent concept album Stillness in Wonderland – fans and critics alike wondered what else Little Simz could do to find the kind of mainstream success enjoyed by so many of her male peers.1332 Solange – When I Get HomeSolange Knowles has never been coy about the intent behind her music. Beautiful arrangements and seamless production notwithstanding, you get the sense, each time she drop a project, that it serves a distinct, zeitgeist-shifting purpose.1432 Foals – Everything Not Saved Will be Lost (Part 1)FoalsMerging their asymmetrical early math pop with the deep space atmospherics of Total Life Forever and Holy Fire, plus added innovations – ambient rainforest throbs on “Moonlight”, deadpan EDM on “In Degrees”, Afro-glitch Radiohead on “Café D’Athens” – they’ve created an inspired album of scorched earth new music that, in all likelihood, will only really be challenged for album of the year by Part 2. (Mark Beaumont)Tracks are at once astute and deeply personal in how they capture vignettes of everyday life and spin them into important lessons. “Black”, the most recent single from the record, considers what that word means to different people around the world, as well as to Dave. “Voices” has him singing over an old-school garage beat, fighting off personal demons.At her best, Sigrid throws out precision-tooled high notes like icicle javelins into vast, blue Scandi-produced skies. Assisted by producer Tim Bidwell, who worked on Rose’s last record Something’s Changing, she sounds braver than she ever has before. There are moments that recall her Communion labelmate Ben Howard, on his latest album, Noonday Dream, and others that nod to the quiet stoicism of Joni Mitchell and Neil Young. (Roisin O'Connor)The record is loosely conceptual insomuch as it’s punctuated with mock adverts for “WWAY HEALTH, our 247 care programme”. But don’t be put off: Miss Universe is a brilliant collection of songs, an expansive melange of indie, jazz, pop and trip-hop that flits between a lo-fi sparseness and something The Strokes would play. Yanya – who is of Turkish-Irish-Bajan heritage – grew up in London on a mix of Pixies, Nina Simone, The Libertines and Amy Winehouse, and this unlikely combination is certainly reflected in the sound. (Patrick Smith)2132 Jenny Lewis – On the LineHere, Lewis does what she does best: adds the glossy sparkle of Hollywood and a sunny Californian sheen to melancholy and nostalgia, with her most luxuriantly orchestrated album yet. It is understood that the rapper arrived at Luton Airport in the early hours of the morning (18 May).Tyler posted a picture of himself standing outside Buckingham Palace on Twitter and&nbsphinted that he may be playing a secret show later in the day, with the photograph's caption reading: “LONDON IGOR 3PM WILL UPDATE YOU LATER WITH LOCATION.”The Independent has reached out to Tyler’s representatives for confirmation on whether the ban has been lifted.Tyler released his sixth album IGOR yesterday (18 May). title: brexit deal latest labour tory compromise commons vote mps eu
story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the optionsFocus on securing Brexit agreement leads to lack of new legislation, as&nbspuncertainty forces some MPs to miss medical appointments while others step&nbspup leadership plottingClick to followIndy PoliticsMPs&nbspfrom across the House of Commons have expressed their anger at the lack of action in parliament after weeks in which the Brexit deadlock has left&nbspthe&nbspCommons with almost nothing to do.There has not been a significant&nbspvote in the Commons since 10 April and on several occasions MPs have&nbspbeen sent home hours earlier than scheduled because there was&nbspnothing for them to debate.Attempts to secure agreement for a Brexit deal have&nbspmonopolised&nbspministers' attention, meaning other legislation has all but dried up.On Monday, the Commons sat for just three and a half hours, beginning at 2.30pm and&nbsprising shortly after 6pm, rather than the usual 10pm.The&nbsplull began after Theresa May's Brexit deal was rejected for a third time at the end of March and the government entered into talks with Labour in a bid to break the&nbspdeadlock.With parliament still gridlocked, MPs said they were very frustrated at having to kill time in Westminster when they could be&nbspworking&nbspin their constituencies. Some predicted that the situation would not improve until there is a new government with a Commons&nbspmajority.&nbspGovernment has spent too much time on Brexit, voters sayFormer Conservative Party vice chairman Ben Bradley told The Independent: “The reason there aren’t more votes is presumably that the government isn’t confident it can win them.The Mansfield MP said he was spending more time on his role on the education select committee and doing constituency events, saying: “I’m just trying to do something useful…it’s nice having the flexibility and spending more time in the constituency but equally because nobody knows what’s going on, you get dragged down here for no reason.“I got down at 4 o'clock&nbspon Monday having been told we must come because there was a vote, but by 6 o’clock we were told we could go home. It’s a total waste of my time travelling and it’s a waste of the cost of the train tickets. Nobody knows what is going on. I get thousands of requests to come to village fetes and local community events and I could be going and doing more of them.Suggesting that&nbspnothing would change until Ms May resigns, he added: People are very frustrated. It’s just the waiting. Everybody knows what needs to happen and it’s not happening and we haven’t got the tools to make it happen - only the cabinet and the 1922 Committee can do that.&nbspWe’re all just treading water.Mr Bradley said the lack of Commons action had&nbspallowed time for prospective Conservative leadership candidates to step up&nbsptheir bids to succeed Theresa&nbspMay.He said: “There’s a lot of plotting going on – that fills a lot of time. A lot of people are off helping the leadership campaigns or having lots of coffees with people who would like to be the new leader. But I think most people are trying to spend as little time here as possible.”Created with Sketch.Opposing protesters flock to parliament on would be date of Brexit Show all 30Created with ParliamentLabour's Chris Bryant, who is receiving treatment for skin cancer, said uncertainty over the Commons schedule had forced&nbspMPs&nbspto missing important medical appointments.He said: I've been travelling back and forth to Wales for medical appointments but two women MPs have told me they've put off smear tests because they're not sure they'll be able to get there because they don't know what the business will be for the next day. It's the same for other types of screening - a male MP told me he'd had to miss a prostate test.Other people can't get home to put their kids to bed. I'm sure it's not much fun at the moment for anybody who has got young kids.Describing&nbspthe situation that&nbspMPs find themselves in, he said: It's like being stuck in the middle of an ocean in the doldrums waiting for a breeze, not even&nbspbothering to mount a mutiny because if you pushed them into a boat, they'd just sit there for another four weeks...It's a very strange parliament.He added: It's completely unprecedented. Half the time the government benches are empty and we're busying ourselves on our side but the one thing we can't do is introduce legislation or pass spending plans...It's a phantom government.Liberal Democrat&nbspMP Sir Ed Davey said the inaction in parliament was giving him more time to focus on constituency work and campaigns, but criticised the government for an appalling lack of activity.He said: If you're a&nbspfastidious MP there's so much&nbspyou can do regardless of what the government is doing, mostly in the constituency. I have a lot of advice and casework so when parliament isn't busy, I'm always doing work in the constituency. If&nbspanyone is twiddling their thumbs, they're not doing the job properly...Parliament doesn't&nbsphave to be sitting and active for MPs to be involved in important politics things.That said, this&nbspgovernment is&nbspthe most incompetent, inefficient, ineffective&nbspgovernment I have ever known. For parliament not to be addressing key issues, whether it is&nbspclimate change or&nbspschool budget cuts or rising crime - the government doesn't really seem as engaged as it could be....The lack of decision-making and the lack of urgency is appalling.He added: The&nbspgovernment is incapable of using its power to address the issues of the country...It's totally unprecedented.&nbspI don't think there's been a time like this.Independent MP Frank Field, who chairs the Commons work and pension committee, said he had urged Ms May&nbspto prioritise bills from backbenchers and select committees in order to give MPs something to debate.He said: Aside from the occasional skirmish on Brexit, parliament has had very little to do in recent months.“In an attempt to fill the domestic reform vacuum, I submitted a proposal to the prime minister for the government to give the necessary time and protection to bills presented by backbenchers, as well as select committees, that are approved by the cabinet’s legislative committee. Had this approach been picked up, we could have had a major domestic reform programme without waiting for Brexit.”Created with Sketch.The front pages on what would have been Brexit Day Show all issues such as circus animals or a lease for Kew Gardens.“We’re still in the first session of a new parliament so you’d expect the government to be bringing forward very wide-ranging or significant bills, but beyond Brexit we’re absolutely not seeing that at the moment.She added: “It looks like a government in the final session of a parliament, where essentially they are doing little bits and It’s not what you would be expecting in the first session…Essentially they are filling time.”The lack of attention given to issues beyond Brexit has also been noticed by the public.A poll for&nbspThe Independent found that almost three-quarters of voters believe the government has focused too much on Brexit&nbspat the expense of other matters.The BMG survey found that 74 per cent of people&nbspsaid ministers had “forgotten” about important domestic issues.Institute for GovernmentThe latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: IM Subscribe &nbsp registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe &nbsp registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 1 monthSee the options'I'm with Brenda from Bristol,' says health secretary Matt HancockClick to followIndy PoliticsAn early general election risks killing Brexit and Theresa May's successor must avoid going to the public until the UK has left the EU, a cabinet minister has warned.Health secretary Matt Hancock made the remarks as a survey of Conservative members made Boris Johnson the clear favourite to succeed the prime minister, and as cross-party talks between the government and Labour collapsed without a deal.Len McCluskey - the Union union boss and close ally of Jeremy Corbyn - demanded a true people's vote in the form of a general election on Friday, saying the UK faced the prospect of a hard Brexiteer as prime minister.But Mr Hancock, who is expected to enter the contest for the Tory leadership when the prime minister formally kicks off the process, said whoever won the premiership had to deliver on Brexit before considering a general election.&nbspI think a general election before we've delivered Brexit would be a disaster. People don't want it. I'm with Brenda from Bristol. We need to take responsibility for delivering on the referendum result, Mr Hancock told The Daily .&nbspCreated with Sketch.Farage launches his new Brexit Party: in pictures Show all 10Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Nigel Farage speaks at the launch of his new Brexit Party's campaign for the European electionsBrexit Party candidate Annunziata Rees-Mogg, sister of Conservative MP Jacob Rees-Mogg, speaks at the launchA supporter waits for Farage to speakSupporters wait for Farage to speakFarage and prospective candidate Annunziata Rees-Mogg wait at the launchSupporters listen as Farage speaksFree T-shirts for all attendees Posters on the seats for supporters of the Brexit PartyNigel Farage speaks at the launch of his new Brexit Party's campaign for the European electionsBrexit Party candidate Annunziata Rees-Mogg, sister of Conservative MP Jacob Rees-Mogg, speaks at the launchA supporter waits for Farage to speakSupporters wait for Farage to speakFarage and prospective candidate Annunziata Rees-Mogg wait at the launchSupporters listen as Farage speaksFree T-shirts for all attendees Posters on the seats for supporters of the Brexit PartyWho knows what the outcome of a general election would be under these circumstances? A general election before that not only risks Jeremy Corbyn, but it risks killing Brexit altogether.We've got to deliver Brexit in this parliament, then we can move forward.The health secretary's comments also came as Ms May faced growing clamour from within her own party to step down immediately in the aftermath of the collapse in talks between the government and the Labour Party.Mr Corbyn dramatically pulled the plug on cross-party talks after more than six weeks, saying they had “gone as far as they can” and the parties had been “unable to bridge important policy gaps”.&nbspMay faces calls to quit now after collapse of cross-party Brexit talksCBI demands MPs cancel spring break to resolve Brexit crisisLib Dems overtake Labour in the polls for Euro electionsIt is unsurprising that the cross-party Brexit talks have collapsedMay blames Labour isions over referendum for end of Brexit talksEarlier this week Ms May bowed to pressure to agree a timetable at the start of next month for a Conservative leadership contest if she – as many in Westminster expect – loses a critical vote on her Brexit legislation.But after the breakdown in the negotiations, the former minister David Jones said the PM should recognise that “now is the time that she should stand down”“On the Conservative benches, most people now want the PM to step down as quickly as possible,”&nbsphe told The Independent. “Prolonging this is just wasting time at a time when we don’t have much time to waste.”The latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxThe latest news on Brexit direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. He said: 'It is absolutely clear a homosexual should not be a teacher'The scandal has come just a week before Austria votes in elections for the European parliament and could lead to a snap election.Mr Kurz is expected to speak at 2pm on Saturday.This is huge. This has to be the end of Heinz-Christian Strache, political analyst Thomas Hofer said before the&nbspresignation.Norbert Hofer, who will replace Mr Strache as vice chancellor and leader of the FPO, ran for president in 2016 and only narrowly lost.Austria approves ban on religious headscarves in primary schoolsThe Kurier newspaper, without citing its sources, said Mr Kurz would prefer to call a fresh election rather than continue to govern with a partner whose image had been tarnished by the affair.Mr Kurz's party still leads opinion polls but they are far short of a majority. The only other party with enough seats for a majority is the Social Democrats, with which Mr Kurz, an immigration hardliner, has difficult relations.Mr Strache has headed the Freedom Party since 2005, bringing it back to mainstream electoral success not seen since it was led by the charismatic Joerg Haider. It secured 26 per cent of the vote in 2017's parliamentary election.The video footage was reported on Friday by two of neighbouring Germany's leading publications – the weekly Der Spiegel and the newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung – purportedly showing a meeting in Ibiza between Mr Strache, another party official and a woman purporting to be the niece of a Russian oligarch.Mr Strache did not reply to a request for comment about the video. Reuters was not able to verify the authenticity of the footage independently and the German newspapers did not say how they obtained it.The newspaper reports said the video appeared to be a sting operation.The&nbspFPO&nbspco-chairman, Christian Hafenecker, said on Friday the party's lawyers were evaluating the material.Neither Mr Strache nor the FPO ever received or granted any benefits from the persons concerned, Mr Hafenecker said in a statement.Since the video was obviously recorded illegally, we are also preparing appropriate legal steps.‘Grannies Against the Right’ fight Austria’s populist politicsAustria arrests former army colonel on suspicion of spying for RussiaAustria follows US and Hungary by withdrawing from migration pactAustria's far-right controlled interior ministry in press freedom rowAustria and Germany pledge to 'do all we can' to avoid hard BrexitThe footage, recorded in July 2017&nbsp– months before the election that brought this government to power – showed Mr Strache talking to the woman.In it, he appeared to offer to direct inflated construction contracts to a company in exchange for support for his party, though he also said he wanted everything to be done legally.Vienna prosecutors said they would study the reports and decide whether there was sufficient cause to open an investigation, a spokesperson for the prosecutors said.The FPO is finished, ran the headline in the tabloid Kronen Zeitung, which featured in the video since the woman said the oligarch wanted to buy a stake.It remains unclear who was behind the recording.Only the best news in your inboxOnly the best news in your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: administration meaning uk companies bust coast
story: Heres what we know about the UK companies to have gone into administration - and what that means...When a company enters administration, all control is passed to an appointed administrator - who has to be a licensed insolvency practitioner.Their goal is to leverage the companys assets and business to repay creditors.Once the administrator has taken over, a moratorium is placed around the company and stops all legal actions.After the administrator takes over, there isnt much that can be done to reverse the process.Between April and June  alone there were  administrations in the UK, and that rate doesnt appear to have slowed down.Liquidation is slightly dferent to administration.Where administration aims to help the company repay its debts, liquidation is the process of selling all assets being then dissolving the company completely.This essentially means that liquidation signals the end of the business it ceases to trade and all assets are liquidated into cash.The administrator will write to your creditors and Companies House to say they’ve been appointed.They will try to stop the company being liquidated butthey cant, the administrator will pay as much of a companys debts as possible from the assets.The administrator has eight weeks to write a statement explaining what they plan to do.This must be sent to creditors, employees and Companies House and invites them to approve or amend the plans at a meeting.According to gov.uk, the administrator could: Russell Hume is the latest firm to go bust in the UK.A number of familiar high street names have hit the rocks in recent years, such as:

title: european elections uk candidates brexit party
story: But who are the candidates and which parties have launched their campaign  Here’s what we know.Seats in England, Scotland and Wales are given to parties based on their share of the vote for candidates on lists created by the parties.In Northern Ireland, the country elects MEPs using a single transferable vote system where voters are able to rank candidates by preference.The Labour Party, Liberal Democrats, the Brexit Party and Ukip have all selected  candidates across the  regions.The Conservative Party has  candidates standing.Change UK originally selected , but two have stepped down over controversy surrounding their social media posts.The Green Party has  candidates standing in England and Wales and has six candidates for the Scottish Greens.Leaders of the SDLP, the Alliance Party, TUV as well as Sinn Fein’s Martina Anderson, DUP’s Diane Dodds and Ulster Unionist minister Danny Kennedy are standing in the election for the parties in Northern Ireland.In Wales, Plaid Cymru has four candidates running in the election.The SNP have six candidates in Scotland.The Brexit Party is currently surging ahead, according to the latest poll data from Pollsters, carried out on May , .Farages party was found to come out on top after analysing the results from the past four polls on voting intention.The Brexit Party secured  per cent of the vote compared to Labour on  per cent and the Conservatives on just  per cent.The parties backing a second referendum on EU membership - the Lib Dems, Greens and Change UK - collectively had a share of  per cent.This compared with the  per cent for Ukip and Brexit who are strongly for leaving the EU.Countries in the EU will vote on May ,  with the results expected on May .Change UKConservativesThe Green PartyThe Liberal DemocratsLabourNorthern Ireland PartiesPlaid CymruSNPThe Brexit PartyUkipOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: disgraceful behaviour joseph mccann indulged
story: Whether he is innocent or guilty, Joseph McCann is facing  charges which include eight rapessix other sexual offences, four kidnaps, two  imprisonments and a charge of assault.Yet, when the time came for him to face these charges in a preliminary hearing at London’s Westminster Magistrates’ Court last week, he refused to emerge from the cells below and was ed to Belmarsh prison. Chief Magistrate Emma Arbuthnot then tried to get him via video link from jail, but he again refused to participate.In , when -year-old Toronto woman Rehab Dughmosh refused to appear in court on terror-related charges, even liberal old Canada issued an “extremely rare” legal order for the wonderfully phrased “cell extraction”.Five officers were given the authority to,necessary, restrain and drag her to court by the scruff of her neck even , as one court official put it: “It may require shackles on the hands and feet.”Sounds perfectly reasonable to me.So, did -year-old McCann, from Aylesbury, Bucks, get the same treatment  Dream on. Instead, the judge, court clerk and prosecution and defence teams were all forced to up sticks and travel  miles to the prison with, don’t laugh, the official court crest in an Argos carrier bag.There, the judge visited McCann in the healthcare wing, where he refused to confirm his name, wouldn’t stand and, at one point, reportedly turned his back to the impromptu hearing before stating he had “been stitched up”.And it seems he’s not alone in this disgraceful behaviour that’s being indulged by our pathetically weak “justice” system.Last year, Gloucester’s top judge, Jamie Tabor QC, said it has now “become fashionable for defendants to refuse to come to court”, noting that the worrying trend started around two years earlier.Yet as far back as , convicted drug dealer Amir Ali refused to attend a confiscation hearing at Lewes Crown Court in East Sussex because he feared losing his cell to another inmate while he was away and claimed it was a breach of his human rights.At the time, Judge Richard Hayward lashed out at the “barking mad” rules stemming from the  Human Rights Act. He added: “I didn’t know that prisoners could choose whether or not to come to court. I just assumed they would be scooped up by a burly prison warden and dumped in the back of a van.” So did we, Judge. So did we.Yet here we are,  years later, still allowing the human rights of an alleged criminal to run roughshod over the court’s authority.IT’S rumoured that -year-old Grace Jones may be filming a scene with Daniel Craig for the upcoming th Bond movie. Cue much excitement about unleashing the power of the older woman, yada yada.Bring it on. But let’s hope Ms Jones’ character fares better than the last time an “older actress” was announced, amid much fanfare, for the movie Spectre.It was -year-old Monica Bellucciand the scene involved her being groped up against a wall by Daniel Craig, who then left her languishing in a basque and stockings while he went off and fell in love with someone younger.The earth may well have moved for Monica’s character, but ground-breaking it was not.MADELEINE McCANN would have been  on Sunday. Sweet . The age when girls start to blossom into young women, steal our make-up and clothes, have myriad crushes and secrets we might never find out about.Instead, her parents Kate and Gerry have passed another torturous year of not knowing whether she’s dead or alive.Wishing their daughter a happy birthday on their Find Maddie Facebook page, they added: “We love you and we’re waiting for you and we’re never going to give up.”Spending a quiet day at home with their other two children, they reportedly placed presents in Maddie’s room and blew out the candles on a commemorative cake.To not celebrate would perhaps feel like an abandonment of hope. My heart goes out to them and all the other parents of missing children. What they’ve been through – and continue to endure – is unimaginable.THE first rule of “modern friendship”, apparently, is never failing to “like” or comment on a pal’s social media posts.PRINCE CHARLES is advertising for a gardener to tend the herbaceous borders of his house on Scotland’s vast Balmoral Estate.Their skill set should include a love of the outdoors, green fingers and, presumably, the ability to e out of harm’s way should Prince Philip ever choose to drive over for a visit.A GP surgery in Cambridgeshire has hired staff who speak a record  languages to cope with patients born abroad.GENTLEMAN JACK actress Suranne Jones reveals that producers brought in an “intimacy director” to make sure the TV show’s sex scenes “do right by the lesbian community”.Nice workyou can get it. In fact, The Bloke is suddenly considering a change of career.ARE you feeling a bit down   How about a week at a £-a-night retreat set in  acres of tropical gardens on the island of Mustique The Cotton House is run by an old chum of Meghan – now the Duchess of Sussex – and was mentioned on the royal couple’s Instagram account as part of their desire to “shine a light” on those doing “amazing work for mental health”.Hmmm. One of the key factors in being a successful royal is to sympathise with the plight of the less well off proles, or at the very least pretend to.This blatant plug for a friend’s luxury bolthole fails on both counts.LONDON Mayor hopeful Shaun Bailey says university quotas for black students would be ultimately “debilitating” because it would make them feel they didn’t have people’s “respect”.He’s right. I feel the same way about women-only shortlists.Chances are you’ll get what you’re after by being the best candidate.Butyou rule out other potential competitors on the basis of race or gender, you’ll be forever blighted by the whispers of numpties insinuating you got it by social engineering, rather than merit.EVER wonder why some of those pregnant models flogging you maternity clothes don’t look bloated   It’s because many of them aren’t “with child” at all. They’re wearing a fake bump.We already have to tolerate those ads for disability aids that feature a thirtysomething with the agility of a mountain goat simply because companies clearly feel that showing hair loss, wrinkles and bunions is a little too much reality.Now we’re being flogged the illusion thatwe buy certain maternity clothes, we too might swerve the plight of swollen ankles and Popeye arms.Fat chance.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: labour nia griffith sacking plot veterans
story: Defence Secretary Penny Mordaunt said she plans to bring in laws to stop ex-troops being charged after a time limit of  years unless overwhelming new evidence comes to light.Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Grfith appeared to back the move, saying she supports “measures to deal with  or vexatious claims”.But she is facing a furious backlash from leftie activists who have demanded Jeremy Corbyn boot her out.In an open letter, over  Corbynista activists – including Momentum boss Jon Lansman – demanded her sacking.They raged: “We the undersigned wish to register our profound disappointment with Nia Grfith’s support for the government’s proposals to grant members of the armed forces immunity from prosecution.“We believe that Nia Grfith must resign as she can no longer credibly represent the party. If she does not, the leadership must take action.”Ms Grfith – a leading Labour moderate – has repeatedly clashed with CND-backing Jeremy Corbyn and his pacist supporters.She backs Britain’s Trident nuclear deterrent – which Mr Corbyn has spent his political career campaigning against.Ms Grfith backs our nuclear deterrent and solid defence spending — and supports our military against  claims like those that saw our Iraq ­veterans wrongly accused.So Corbynistas want her out. And these idiots hold sway over a party that the Tories’ implosion could put in power.Britain will not be safe under Corbyn’s feeble pacism.Facing the wrath of leftie activists, Ms Grfiths was forced to clary her remarks.She said: “I did not say that British Forces, or indeed any group of people, should be above the law.”She added: “Labour opposes any blanket immunity, and the International Criminal Court itself makes clear that statutes of limitation for the most serious crimes are not permitted in any circumstances – this is obviously right.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: get brexit in any form now or the country faces having jeremy corbyn in no10
story: The chances of her Brexit deal passing in three weeks are zero, or close to it.A new Tory leader and PM is desperately needed, to inspire some hope in the country, the Government and party.Maybe he or she can reset Brexit talks, or even steer us out with No Deal. But they will face the same problems and the same Commons mathematics.Even now The Sun believes getting Brexit over the line, even via Mrs May’s deal, is the best option. Why  Because not doing so leads almost inevitably to a Corbyn Government.And that is worse than anything Brexit, in any form, could throw at our country.ANYONE still in doubt about left-wing bias at the supposedly impartial BBC Yesterday it let leftie website Huffington Post run Radio . Were the Beeb’s army of young left-wing hacks all off  Why did they need to call in their soulmates from this online outfit But it’s not just the bias. It’s that they handed a commercial organisation free publicity worth a fortune. title: highland estate loch ness monster sale
story: A ,-acre estate on the banks of Loch Ness has gone on sale this week - boasting sprawling grounds and unparalleled views of the Scottish lake.The Bunloit estate near Drumnadrochit, Inverness, Scotland is being sold by property firm Strutt  Parker.It boasts a library with -degree views of the highlands, a greenhouse, a spacious kitchen, and three cosy bedrooms.The estate centres on The Old School House, a former school that operated from  to .It has been converted into a spacious family home with spectacular views of the Great Glen.Former pupils recall carrying a pint of milk and a square of peat to the school every day.Kevin Maley, head of residential agency for Strutt  Parker in Scotland, said: Positioned near the ruins of Urquhart Castle and offering stunning panoramic views of Loch Ness and the Monadhliath Mountains, Bunloit offers the seclusion and romance of a traditional Scottish estate combined with the convenience of proximity to Inverness.This is a lovely manageable mixed estate with a very attractive principal house in a magical location.There is also scope to develop with the potential to build upon both the holiday accommodation business and the sportings available.

title: baby elephant thailand zoo animal cruelty
story: Last month, sickening footage of a distressed baby elephant being forced to rave for the amusements of tourists went viral.The skeletal calf in the video was growing weaker every day as it was forced to dance and perform tricks - until April , when the animals two back legs snapped.The baby elephants legs were broken for three days before he was taken to hospital to be treated, and he died just one week later on April .Campaign group Moving Animals, who filmed the video that went viral, named the baby elephant Dumbo when it started a petition to have him released.The petition garnered over , signatures in just one week, with many people outraged that the animal could be made to perform in such poor health.Amy Jones, co-founder of Moving Animals, said: “This is a tragic and horric end to Dumbo’s heartbreakingly-short le.”“His skeletal body clearly suggested that he was unwell and could be suffering from malnourishment and exhaustion. And yet the zoo did nothing until receiving international criticism. Under their care, this baby elephant broke both of his back legs, and the zoo did not even realise for three days.I can’t bring myself to imagine Dumbo’s suffering during this time.”“For Dumbo to die whilst under the so-called care and treatment of the zoo shows just how neglected these animals are in captivity.”The baby elephant broke its back legs when its front legs became stuck in a puddle of mud.He was attempting to hold himself up with just his back legs on dry ground, but both legs were so weak that they snapped.Phuket Zoo, which housed the animal, is free to acquire another baby elephantthey choose to do so.Dumbo was obviously ill in the footage that went viral last month.After he was hospitalised, a vet revealed that he had had an infection in his digestive tract for months.He told local newspapers: “He had an infection that resulted in constant diarrhoea, which caused other health complications, including the fact that his body was not absorbing nutrients as it should, which made him very weak.Moving Animals are urging tourists never to pay to see animals in captivity.Jones said: No animal deserves to repeat Dumbos tragic story.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: selena gomez leigh anne pinnock ignore trolls
story: The hugely successful actress and singer has an astonishing MILLION followers on Instagram and is one of the most influential young women on the planet.So when Selena declared this week social media has been “terrible” for her entire generation, we should all take heed. The -year-old has a wise head on those young shoulders.She realises just how toxic s like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook can be and understands the long-term damage they cause.We are already in a very dark place when it comes to these s.This week there was the utterly heartbreaking story of a -year-old girl in Malaysia who took her own le after asking her social media followers whether or not she should do so.Appallingly,  per cent of her Instagram followers voted that she should kill herself. So she did.This young woman, with everything to live for, jumped off a high building in Sarawak, Borneo, and her le was snuffed out. Apparently the poor kid, who has not been named, had a history of depression and was clearly seeking some sort of help or validation via social media.Instead, some seriously sick and callous people encouraged her to die.This is the kind of appalling tragedy Selena is concerned about. She wants people to be more supportive of one another online and to spread kindness instead of cruelty and hatred.Selena has had a tough time of her own battling mental health problems after being struck down by lupus, a disease that attacks the immune system and which forced her to undergo a kidney transplant.She took a long break from Instagram and is now extremely careful about what she posts.Selena has spoken eloquently about the young fans she meets who talk to her about being bullied online and feeling powerless to defend themselves.I am so glad I grew up in a time before my mistakes would be posted for all to see on the internet.I would have been slaughtered on Twitter for my awkward early TV appearances.Instead, I was allowed to learn and improve without being made to feel like a failure.I have recently abandoned Twitter, as it had become exhaustingly toxic.I mostly use Instagram to post funny pictures of my beloved Border Terrier Angus, or details of my outfits on TV, simply because I get so many people asking which shop they come from.I occasionally receive some pretty horrid comments about my sense of style but I try to ignore them and not to be too hurt.This week I spoke to Leigh-Anne Pinnock of Little Mix.All four young women in the group have been bombarded with negative comments online ever since winning The X Factor in .They are vilied for their appearance and choice of clothes — and sadly, Leigh-Anne has been subjected to disgusting racism too.It’s been so tough for her and for bandmates Jesy, Jade and Perrie, leaving them upset and shaken. It has taken years for them to stop looking at social media and be strong enough to ignore corrosive comments.I happen to think some of their outfits are a bit risque and clearly I wouldn’t wear them myself — but so what  It is their choice andthey want to be a bit naughty and raunchy, they should go for it.I heartily applaud Selena and Leigh-Anne for speaking out and trying to limit the power of hideous trolls.We can’t all be like Piers Morgan, who is bombarded with negative and abusive comments but cheerfully retweets them, correcting the spelling and grammar of even the most appalling insults.We are not all so thick-skinned and, as Selena has pointed out, it’s too late to police social media effectively.Sadly it gives the sickest, most twisted and cruellest people a chance to inflict suffering and mental anguish on the rest of us.The message is simple: Be like Selina and Leigh-Anne. Ignore the trolls, don’t feed them — andyou feel you can’t live without social media, try to be positive and uplting.IF you are in need of an injection of sheer joy and happiness, download the  movie musical Calamity Jane and prepare to be enchanted by a le- affirming performance from the late, great Doris Day.At a time in Hollywood when women were either sex symbols or old maids, Doris gave an ass-kicking lead performance to make us laugh and cry, often in the same scene.Doris, who died this week aged , was a triple threat who could act, sing and dance to perfection. She moved with the greatest of ease from musical dramas like Love Me Or Leave Me and Young At Heart to the frothy comedies Pillow Talk and Move Over Darling.A class act who never felt the need to hang on to the spotlight, she was happy as a clam living in Carmel, Calornia, with her beloved pets, raising money to care for neglected animals.Doris will be sadly missed but what a legacy she leaves behind.GREAT to see top actor Stephen Graham finally getting the attention and praise he so richly deserves.He played a blinder in BBC’s Line Of Duty as a tortured undercover cop and is now burning up the screen in The Virtues on Channel  as a broken alcoholic.It’s an acting masterclass, completely believable and utterly authentic.Last weekend, Jodie Comer made a point of praising Stephen during her acceptance speech for the best actress gong at the Baftas.Jodie won for her mesmerising performance as assassin Villanelle in Killing Eve and was quick to say she owes Stephen a pint for all his support when she started acting.So not only an incredible performer but a kind-hearted and generous one too.We will see him on our screens later this year alongside the star of the new Warburtons adverts, Robert De Niro, as well as Al Pacino and Joe Pesci, in Netflix movie The Irishman, directed by Martin Scorsese.I guarantee Stephen will steal every scene he appears in. This is his golden time and no one deserves it more.ABORTION features currently on two of our TV dramas. In Emmerdale, Victoria Barton has been raped and is now pregnant.And in Holby City, it has been revealed that surgeon Ange was raped as a young woman and decided to go ahead with the pregnancy, keeping daughter Chloe.Both fictional characters have the right to choose what to do with their own bodies – something I firmly believe in.Right now in America, that choice has been taken away from real women living in the very conservative state of Alabama, where abortion has been banned altogether.This means a child, young girl or woman who is raped and discovers she is pregnant will have to go through with the birth.Evenshe is the victim of incest and repeatedly raped by a family member – father, brother or uncle – and is impregnated, she will not be able to have a termination.This is hideous, inhumane and deeply disturbing, especially as the draconian abortion ban is likely to spread into other US states.Right here and now in Alabama, doctors who perform abortions could go to prison for  years and the anti-abortion movement is gaining ground.On Thursday, the Republican-led senate in Missouri passed a Bill to ban abortions, this time at eight weeks. Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio and Georgia have already approved “heartbeat” abortion bans at just six weeks, when most women wouldn’t even realise they are pregnant.Louisiana, South Carolina and Tennessee are set to follow and in other states, legislation is being drawn up to make abortion either more dficult or completely impossible.Aside from some victims of rape and incest, no woman ever goes through with an abortion without suffering horrendous grief and anguish.It’s never a decision taken lightly and we simply cannot go back to the days when pregnant women and the medics who help them are treated like criminals.The US is going backwards at an alarming rate and these laws will simply drive terminations underground, putting women at severe risk of botched backstreet abortions that can maim for le or even kill.Shame on every legislator who helped pass these cruel laws.GOOD luck to Michael Rice, who takes to the stage in Tel Aviv desperately hoping not to come last in the Eurovision Song Contest.This is no reflection on his performance or the song Bigger Than Us, which is our best effort in years.It’s down to biased voting to punish the UK for all the Brexit b*****ks.On the surface, Eurovision is a screechingly hilarious fun-filled campfest to be applauded and enjoyed.But underneath, it’s horribly political and rather grubby.We could have Adele and Robbie Williams singing a duet and still come bottom of the heap, such is the depth of anti-British feeling.Michael wasn’t born the last time the UK won Eurovision, with Love Shine A Light by Katrina  The Waves in .Times have changed since those heady days and now anything other than the dreaded “nul points” will be a victory for young Michael.He’s philosophical about his prospects and determined to enjoy sharing the same stage as Madonna in front of the biggest audience of his career. title: chattering classes praise jeremy kyle working classes derision
story: But equally telling is how much criticism of Kyle’s show has revealed a snobbishness about the people who watched and appeared on it.Tory MP Charles Walker called it “unattractive television”. A columnist at the left-leaning New Statesman magazine described it as curating “a morbidly chaotic picture of a British underclass — for those watching at home to scoff and sneer”.Over at the self-appointed moral compass of Britain, , an editorial complained it preyed on “vulnerable, unhappy people”, turning “a blind eye to mental health problems”. writer Zoe Williams had previously claimed: “Jeremy Kyle has created the cultural spectre of this feral underclass, none of whom has the smallest amount of emotional restraint.”Such bile aimed at a show loved by so many — the final episode, on Friday last week, drew over a million viewers — reveals as much about Kyle as who our commentariat feel has the right to speak, and how they are meant to do it.Kyle’s cull comes at a time of unprecedented openness around personal and mental health issues — as middle-class public figures are lauded for sharing their private woes.Yet working-class people airing their issues on daytime TV find themselves derided.Perhaps Kyle’s guests didn’t speak with the right accent or wear the right clothes. They didn’t have impressive jobs or double-barreled names. They did not articulate themselves calmly, via book deals, or break down on Instragram with full faces of make-up.Rather than be celebrated for bravery, they are written off as dysal.Many of Kyle’s guests did not have mental health issues — they were normal people discussing their problems. There were estranged parents, people struggling to trust or dealing with addiction.Kyle gave real people a voice. Among those who have complained about experiences on the show, many have also said it helped them.Although judgmental about his guests’ actions, Kyle did not judge his guests. Open about his own problems, he believed his guests were as capable of turning their lives around as him. This is more credit than many commentators have given them.It’s offensive to hear Kyle’s adult guests written off as “vulnerable”, asincapable of deciding whether to appear. After  years, , episodes and  series, they would have known Kyle’s style. These were adults choosing to share stories on a  that mattered to them.It comes, of course, as royalty, showbiz celebrities and broadsheet columnists have been praised for publicly airing their personal problems. Never have we celebrated sharing these issues so loudly. When Prince Harry spoke of coming close to a breakdown, singer Will Young his struggle with anxiety and model Cara Delevingne her depression, people applauded.They belong to an industry of openness. Books chronicling personal struggles with mental health are being published to acclaim. Such as Susannah Cahalan’s memoir Brain On Fire, about her psychosis. Or Matt Haig’s memoir about depression, Reasons To Stay Alive. Documentaries such as Bake Off winner Nadiya Hussain’s this week, Anxiety And Me, are praised.Sharing such issues is important. Prince Harry, on his tour of Australia, spoke thoughtfully about how people “must not silently suffer” and must share problems because others “will relish the opportunity to listen or talk themselves”. Yet apparently all this admiration for openness does not extend to Kyle’s guests.Charles Walker complained they were “emotional”. This from a man commended for speaking about his OCD, which he said made him a “practising fruitcake”.Onewriter described Kyle’s guests as “delinquent children, tearaway teens, feckless fathers, long-term unemployed . . . alcoholics, junkies, the sexually insecure, the sexually confused, the sexually poly-amorous” — but could have been describing contributors to the paper’s blog Comment Is Free.District judge Alan Berg described Kyle’s show as “human bear-baiting” and “a morbid and depressing display of dysal people who are in some kind of turmoil”.Asyou couldn’t say the same about many in the House of Commons.The bile for Kyle contrasts, too, with praise of other reality TV — in particular, Love Island. Also aired on ITV, it has seen the suicide of two of its former contestants. Yet the show is celebrated. columnist Leah Green  praised how it “makes the complexities of British society so tangible they can’t be ignored”. Another column in the paper cheered it as “a place where liars and love rats get called out and prejudices are exposed.” It opined: “There is something to be gleaned here about friendship, race . . . and the way men and women communicate.”Perhaps such lessons are just more palatable when they come via men with tanned six-packs and women with perfect teeth.When I watched Kyle’s show I didn’t see a “feral under-class”. I saw people I know. I saw real le, which is messy, dysal and chaotic, which does not always come out in well-formed sentences, memoirs or documentaries made by people with posh accents for Radio .I didn’t watch Kyle to sneer. I watched with relief that some people were truly open about the madness of le. What happens to them now Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may concessions dup brexit deal
story: Senior sources last night claimed the Withdrawal Billgoing before the Commons early next week will be amended to “build the broadest coalition possible”.One concession will see No. commit to alternative arrangements to replace the Irish backstop by the end of .Another will enshrine in law a commitment to regulatory alignment between Britain and Northern Ireland in any trade deal with Brussels.A Government source said: “We’re not just going to bring it back as it was and hope for the best.”The PM will also speak to Cabinet Ministers this weekend before deciding whether to hold a round of ‘Indicative Votes’ on alternative Brexit plans in the Commons before putting the ‘WAB’ before MPs.One senior Tory last night said they believed a No Deal was a “racing certainty”.But one Minister told The Sun they expected a new Tory leader to be forced to accept a second referendum.They said: “I imagine they’ll come in and realise going back to the people is the only way through this.”Theresa May has already suffered three thumping Commons defeats on her Brexit agreement with the EU.She committed earlier this week to effectively hold a fourth and final vote in the week beginning June  by bringing WAB legislation designed to enshrine Brexit in law before MPs.But sources claim she is heading for another defeat of up to  votes.DUP chief Arlene Foster last night once more demanded the Government reject the backstop altogether.In a statement she said the round of talks with Labour had “wasted time”.She said: “It was always doomed to failure.“The Government should reject the backstop and work for a sensible deal which unionists throughout the United Kingdom can support.”She added: “The people voted in  and the result must be implemented.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brian reade rich richer britain
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: The rich get richer in Britain but one idea sounds like a winnerThe Sunday Times Rich List shows Britain’s , wealthiest iniduals now possess a record £.billion between them - with  people now worth more than a billionShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  MAY NewsopinionJulian Richer, the ethical boss "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI never cease to be amazed at the richest people’s ability to keep on being brilliant at what they do. Whereas most normal people have seen no rise in their living standards for a decade, these geniuses just keep smashing their good fortune out of the park. As the annual Sunday Times Rich List shows, Britain’s , wealthiest iniduals now possess a record £.billion, up £.bn on last year, with  people now worth more than a billion. What talent, and ­dedication to your bank balance, that must take. ­Especially as we know it has nothing to do with exploiting ­governments, abusing workers and blatant tax avoidance. Among their number is Sir James Dyson, who upped his wealth by £.bn to £.bn, despite the great patriotic Brexiteer pleading that “economic forces” left him with no option but to move his company’s headquarters to Singapore. They’re also masters at justying their stratospheric growth in riches, claiming it’s good for society as it ­inevitably trickles down.Yet this week, the Charities Aid Foundation reported a noticeable drop in the number of super-rich iniduals donating more than  per cent of their wealth. It’s not just the super-rich, either. It’s the just-about-very-rich. Take Tesco boss Dave Lewis who picked up a £.million annual pay packet months after stating , jobs were at risk in “a major cost-cutting drive”.Well, there’s costs and costs isn’t there  This confirmation of how easy it is to keep getting much more loadedyou’re already loaded, comes in a week when Nobel-prize winning ­economist Sir Angus Deaton claimed Britain is on the road to becoming one of the most unequal nations on Earth.  Pointing out that CEOs of FTSE  firms are now paid  times more than their average worker , Sir Angus issued a warning. “There’s a real question about whether ­democratic capitalism is working, when it is only working for part of the population. People really feel that not everybody is having a fair crack anymore.. But all hope is not lost. We also heard this week that Julian Richer, owner of audio chain Richer Sounds, is handing control of his business to staff now that he’s hit . He is giving them  per cent of his shares and triggering windfalls for  employees, who’ll receive £, for every year they’ve worked there. Richer Sounds refuses to employ people on zero hours contracts, donates  per cent of its profits to charity, and is founded on “the ethical ­principles of being decent, honest and truthful”. And last year, Richer founded Tax Watch UK, an investigative think-tank, dedicated to the research and exposure of aggressive tax-avoiding corporations. Those FTSE billionaires no doubt scoffed at his naivety, especially as he used to be a Tory party donor. How can a chap who used to bat for them turn into a covert Marxist  How can a chap go on Radio , as Richer did this week, and say “inequality in this country is the worst I’ve known in my letime”  I sense a changing mood among some young entrepreneurs and am optimistic more may begin to see the bigger picture.That it’s not all about accumulating a wealth you can never spend and trampling your workers underfoot along the way. That there’s a better definition of success. Maybe in the midst of today’s ­corporate indecency there’s hope for the decent.

title: boy 13 never walk again
story: NewsBoy, , will never walk again after back strain was really rare blood clotKyle Burns, , was at football training in Kilmarnock, Scotland, when he got a pain in his backShareCommentsByAmanda Keenan:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsKyle Burns, , was at football training when he got a pain in his back"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA teenage boy has been left paralysed after suffering from an incredibly rare spinal injury which medics have compared to being shot with a bullet. Kyle Burns, , was at football training when he became unwell and was rushed to Crosshouse Hospital in Kilmarnock. It was thought he had strained his back at Galston Boysapos Club but he collapsed minutes after arriving at AE. Doctors discovered a rare clot on his spinal cord had caused it to rip leaving him with no feeling from the ribs down. The teenager is now facing le in a wheelchair as it is unlikely he will be able to walk again, reports the Daily Record.    Mum Donna, , said: “When doctors told me the news I just ran out the room crying. I couldn’t believe what I was hearing. “Just hours earlier he had been running around playing the sport he lived for and then we were being told Kyle would never walk again.” The promising young player’s injuries were so rare, doctors had to take advice from experts in London before deciding how to proceed. Donna added: “They said the only thing they could compare it to was like someone being shot in the back with a shotgun. “The medical staff said thatKyle had fallen out of a window  storeys high the injuries to his spine wouldn’t have been as severe. “They’ve said they have never had to treat something so bad, that’s how rare it is.”  Doctors diagnosed a fibrocartilaginous embolism, a sudden blocking of an artery which in turn led to a spinal stroke, causing the cord to tear. Medics ruled out surgery and Kyle’s heartbroken family were given the news that there was no treatment to restore his mobility. The tragedy happened last Thursday and the youngster is now facing weeks of gruelling rehabilitation to become strong enough just to use a wheelchair. Donna, from Galston, Ayrshire, added: “I can’t believe this is where we are now. Kyle had come home with his coach complaining of a sore back and walked into accident and emergency. “Within an hour of arriving, he just deteriorated. He collapsed and said to me, ‘Mum, I can’t feel my legs, please help me.’ “The doctors at Crosshouse Hospital couldn’t believe it was the same boy who had come in and he was bluelighted to the spinal ward at the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.” The Loudoun Academy pupil was rushed for MRI scans, which revealed the devastating extent of his injuries. Donna, who is also mum to Jamie, , Thomas, eight, and four-year-old Cooper, decided to wait a few days before breaking the news to Kyle.  She admits the youngster is struggling to come to terms with his paralysis. She said: “It was a massive shock for me and I thought, ‘How on earth do I tell my -year-old son he’s never going to walk again ’ It’s the most dficult thing I’ve ever had to do. I’m trying to stay strong for Kyle. “I’ve spent the last week in tears, I’m heartbroken for him. He dreamed of becoming a footballer and it feels like he’s been robbed of the le he wanted. “I don’t want him to see me upset because I have to stay positive. It’s just such a horrendous thing for any child to go through. The reality hasn’t hit him yet and I don’t think he will really process the extent of it all until he is in a wheelchair. “At the moment, he’s lying in a hospital bed in the spinal unit and can’t really do much. “He starts rehab on Tuesday and being in a wheelchair for the first time will be a big challenge for Kyle. He just can’t get his head around it.”  Donna, who has been allowed to stay by Kyle’s side at the hospital, says the family are overwhelmed by the support they have received from relatives and friends. They have set up a fundraising drive to buy a state-of-the-art electric wheelchair which they hope will give the teen more independence when he is finally allowed home. Donna added: “Kyle is such a popular lad at school and everyone is getting behind him. “He’s not seen any of his friends yet and I think not being able to run around and do the things he is used to will be very tough.  “His football team have been in contact to offer their support. No one can believe this has happened. “He’s the type of wee boy who gives everything  per cent and he’s always been so active. He loves playing football, basketball and rugby but now it has all been taken away from him. “We want to give him the best wheelchair so that he feels more comfortable. He want’s a white one that he thinks looks really cool. “We also have to look at adapting our home in the future to accommodate Kyle’s needs. I’ve promised him we will do everything we can to make it all happen. “It’s going to be a long road and I want him to be able to le his live to the fullest.”To donate, visit  https:www.gofundme xcncv-kyle

title: insurance firm wont pay medical
story: NewsInsurance firm wont pay medical bills for sick dad because he had a drink on holidayDavid Poole, , was taken ill on May  when he was  per cent over the UK limit - even though he wasnt driving when the accident happenedShareCommentsByRaven Saunt:,  MAY NewsDavid Poole and his we were holidaying in Turkey when he was seriously injured "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA gravely ill British tourist is facing a huge medical bill because he was over the drink-drive limit when seriously injured himself.David Poole was placed in intensive care when he suffered a brain haemorrhage on a trip to Turkey, BirminghamLive reports .But now his worried family say they could be hit with a a le-changing bill for the -year-oldaposs care because of the amount of alcohol in his system at the time of his accident. His son, Stuart, said insurers had an issue with his father being around  per cent over the UK limit - even though he was not driving when the accident happened. On Thursday, Mr Pooleaposs family were informed that insurer Rock would not pay costs for his care or an air ambulance flight to get him back home. Stuart, who flew out to Turkey to be by his fatheraposs side, says he is appalled over the insurers move.    He said: This shows a distinct lack of compassion or common sense. My father has a bleed on the brain. All the doctors we spoke to didnapost knowthis was the cause of, or as a result of, the fall. In what is a particularly stressful time for our family, we are having the unnecessary complication of dealing with financial concerns that should be covered by travel insurance. The intentions of my family are to appeal proceedings immediately. The family say they have not yet been made aware of the costs involved with his treatment. Mr Poole was enjoying a getaway with his we Diane, , in the resort of Marmaris when he was taken ill on May . His family believe he may have fallen while walking on the promenade - but are unclear as to the exact circumstances. Mr Poole was first rushed to a local hospital but was transferred to a centre where a specialist neurologist revealed he had suffered a brain haemorrhage. He has been in intensive care for two weeks and remains in a semi-conscious state.    The family booked their holiday through agent Travel Republic and also received confirmation of their police through rock insurance before they left. The family claim the insurance company has now refused to pay out, citing issues over Mr Pooleaposs blood alcohol level. Doctors measured his blood alcohol at . - just over the UK drink-drive limit of . - when he arrived in hospital. Stuart said: We want people to be aware how wishy-washy travel companies are over their alcohol policies. Maybe we are biased but we think it is in the national interest for these clauses to be more publicised, especially with the summer holidays coming up. Mrs Poole, who suffers from Parkinsons, was escorted back to the UK last week. Her husband was her primary care giver. Until July , the couple were both employed by Birmingham City Council as emergency foster carers but were forced to give that up due to the deterioration of Mrs Pooleaposs health. A Travel Republic spokeswoman said: Firstly Travel Republic is very saddened to hear of this incident and would like to wish Mr Poole a speedy recovery. Travel Republic insurance services are provided by Rock Insurance. For regulatory reasons, comment on this specic case is currently restricted due to GDPR constraints, as it is a live and active case.
